metadata.subject: What the Middle East Needs Now from America

organizations: U.S. House Committee on Oversight and Accountability

relationships.description: Barrack is identified as a foreign policy and economic advisor to GOP U.S. Presidential candidate Donald Trump
Described as America's longest and strongest ally in the Middle East for over seventy years
Emerging alliance between Putin and Erdogan noted

analysis.purpose: To critique past U.S. foreign policy in the Middle East and propose a new strategy focusing on economic development and alliances with Arab leaders
analysis.significance: Represents the foreign policy views of a key advisor to Donald Trump during the 2016 presidential campaign, outlining a significant shift in Middle East approach

notable_quotes: "America's nation-building exercise of the past twenty years was founded on self-contradictions that have tarnished US foreign credibility."

"Saudi Arabia has been our longest and strongest ally and, to many Westerners' amazement, it is impossible for the US to move against any hostile Islamic group anywhere in the world without Saudi support."
"Bashar Assad may well be our only hope in fighting the various terrorist factions that are attempting to form an ISIS state."
red_flags: Advocacy for working with controversial regimes like Assad's Syria
Suggestion that Saudi Arabia should have veto power over U.S. actions against Islamic groups

blackmail_indicators.description: No indicators of blackmail or coercion found; this is a policy commentary article

illegal_activity.description: This is a published Fortune magazine article sharing policy commentary, not evidence of first-hand illegal activity

details: This document itself is a Fortune magazine article/commentary piece

public_knowledge.context: This was a publicly published article in Fortune magazine during the 2016 presidential campaign, representing views of a Trump advisor

analysis.summary: Thomas J. Barrack Jr., a Trump campaign advisor, critiques U.S. Middle East policy as flawed 'embrace and abandon' strategy and proposes working with Arab allies like Saudi Arabia and even Assad's Syria to combat terrorism through economic development rather than nation-building.
